name: Cumulative Distribution Function (CDF)
description:
Let $X$ be a $\mathbb{R}^d$ Random variable defined on $(\Omega, \mathbb{P})$. We define the following function as the CDF: $$F_x(t)=\mathbb{P}(\{\omega\in\Omega: X(\omega)\leq t\})$$ Note that $F_x:\mathbb{R}\mapsto\mathbb{R}$. All information about $X$'s distribution is contained in the CDF $F_X$ so we will often work with the CDF of a random variable. If $X$ is a continuous random variable, then its PDF $p_X(d)$ is also defined such that: $$p_X(t)=\frac{d}{dt}F_X(t)$$ Note that the CDF and PDF determine each other. We can get the PDF via $p_X(t)=\frac{d}{dt}F_X(t)$, and we can get the CDF via $F_X(t)=\int_{-\infty}^t p_X(x)dx)$. Equivalently, all information about $X$'s distribution is contained in the PDF $p_X$ as well.

Basic properties of the CDF include:
 1. $F_x(t)$ is a non-decreasing function (if $t_1\leq t_2$ then $F_x(t_1) \leq F_x(t_2)$).
 2. $\lim_{t\rightarrow-\infty}F_X(t)=0$ and $\lim_{t\rightarrow\infty}F_X(t)=1$
